Platte Basin Timelapse

Seeing a Watershed in Motion

The Platte River Basin

The Platte River is a major river system in the heart of the Great Plains. Forming high the Rocky Mountains in Colorado, the North and South Platte River flow through Wyoming and Colorado, before joining on the plains of Nebraska. The Loup River drains the Nebraska Sandhills, joining with the central Platte in eastern Nebraska, finishing the over 20,000 mile journey at it's confluence with the Missouri River on the eastern border of Nebraska.

Along it's path, the Platte River is complex, managed, enjoyed, and used by a variety of stakeholders and influences. We would to share that with you.

Facts About the Platte Basin

Spreads over 90,000 square miles

Covers parts of Three States

Houses over 500 communities

Provides habitat for Four Endangered Speices

Runs 519 Streams and hundreds of unnamed

Contains Five Ecoregions

Provides as the Breadbasket of the U.S.

90,000 square miles

One Photo, Every Hour, Every Day

Seeing a Watershed in Motion

Timelapse cameras are installed at important locations throughout the Platte Basin. Powered by solar panels, they automatically take one photo, every daylight hour of everyday, allowing us to capture a moment in time, when no one else is there.

With timelapse imagery, we can see both time and place evolve as never before seen. Days, months, and years go by in minutes and even seconds. Through this, one can be inspired and learn the story of this river, the lifeblood of our region.

Understanding the story of the Platte River allows us to become better citizens and stewards of our communities, our homes, and our basin. Check back regularly on the website to find continued updates from our cameras.
